reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus moral trade/compromise can plausibly steer toward a mostly-great future (section 3 and the conclusion treat this as the most promising route). If this mechanism is systematically incentive-incompatible, that meaningfully weakens the essay’s outlook, though it wouldn’t fully collapse the broader position (which also discusses WAM-convergence, blockers, and other paths). The argument has real force: trade premised on asymmetric moral intensity can create incentives for strategic exaggeration, commitment to extortion, and selection effects that favor credible defectors over sincere moral agents, pushing allocations away from “correctness.” However, it doesn’t fully refute the trade route because (i) the essay already anticipates a nearby problem in 3.3 (threats/extortion) and flags institutional prevention as pivotal, and (ii) the critique overstates inevitability (“in equilibrium…”) without engaging possible mitigations (verification/skin-in-the-game, mechanism design, reputational equilibria, anti-extortion norms/contracts, limiting negotiable domains). Overall it’s clear, mostly accurate as a risk claim, low on fluff, and focused on a single issue, but only moderately damaging given partial overlap with acknowledged concerns and lack of engagement with countermeasures.
title: Moral trade rewards strategic misrepresentation over genuine value convergence
